<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 232, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 242, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 730, 728]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
An athlete has mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\). The athlete runs along a horizontal road against a constant resistance force of magnitude \(24 \mathrm{N}\). The total work done by the athlete in increasing his speed from \(5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to \(6 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) while running a distance of 50 metres is \(1541 \mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 277, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(3\mathrm{kg}\) and \(6\mathrm{kg}\) respectively, lie on a smooth horizontal plane. Initially, \(B\) is at rest and \(A\) is moving towards \(B\) with speed \(8\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). After \(A\) and \(B\) collide, \(A\) moves with speed \(2\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 779, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the greater of the two possible total losses of kinetic energy due to the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 129, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 81, 774, 152]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
A particle of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is going to be pulled across a rough horizontal plane by a light inextensible string. The string is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) above the plane and has tension \(T\mathrm{N}\) (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between the particle and the plane is 0.5 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 144, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 692, 247]]<|/det|>
Given that the particle is on the point of moving, find the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 229, 917, 247]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 186, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 757, 618]]<|/det|>
Given instead that the particle is accelerating at \(0.2 \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\), find the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
A particle moves in a straight line. It starts from rest, at time \(t = 0\), and accelerates at \(0.6t \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\) for \(4 \mathrm{s}\), reaching a speed of \(V \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\). The particle then travels at \(V \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) for \(11 \mathrm{s}\), and finally slows down, with constant deceleration, stopping after a further \(5 \mathrm{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 146, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 311, 158]]<|/det|>
Show that \(V = 4.8\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 144, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 504, 344]]<|/det|>
Sketch a velocity-time graph for the motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 325, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 779, 90]]<|/det|>
Find an expression, in terms of \(t\), for the velocity of the particle for \(15 \leqslant t \leqslant 20\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 90]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 185, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 320, 522, 338]]<|/det|>
Find the total distance travelled by the particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 79, 648, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 299, 920, 350]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(3\mathrm{kg}\) and \(5\mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are connected by a light inextensible string that passes over a fixed smooth pulley. The particles are held with the string taut and its straight parts vertical. Particle \(A\) is \(1\mathrm{m}\) above a horizontal plane, and particle \(B\) is \(2\mathrm{m}\) above the plane (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 363, 920, 396]]<|/det|>
The particles are released from rest. In the subsequent motion, \(A\) does not reach the pulley, and after \(B\) reaches the plane it remains in contact with the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 146, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 720, 426]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the time taken for \(B\) to reach the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 272, 143, 289]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 623, 291]]<|/det|>
Find the time for which \(A\) is at least \(3.25 \text{m}\) above the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
